unnormalised: The donation box at the Gurudwara always fascinated me. As a kid, I’d watch my grandmother carefully count out notes, usually adding up to ₹501 or maybe even ₹1001 on special occasions. She always explained it was for langar, ensuring everyone had a hot meal. I didn't quite grasp the concept of charity then, but I understood it was important to her.
normalised: The donation box at the Gurudwara always fascinated me. As a kid, I’d watch my grandmother carefully count out notes, usually adding up to rupee five hundred and one or maybe even rupee one thousand and one on special occasions. She always explained it was for langar, ensuring everyone had a hot meal. I didn't quite grasp the concept of charity then, but I understood it was important to her.

unnormalised: Years later, during the Kerala floods, I saw the power of collective giving. News channels showed people donating everything from ₹100 to ₹10,000, sometimes even more, to relief funds. There were stories of NRIs sending USD 500 and more, all aimed at helping those affected. It was overwhelming, but also incredibly inspiring. It made me realize charity wasn't just about religious obligations; it was about humanity.
normalised: Years later, during the Kerala floods, I saw the power of collective giving. News channels showed people donating everything from rupee one hundred to rupee ten thousand, sometimes even more, to relief funds. There were stories of N-R-I-s sending U-S-D five hundred and more, all aimed at helping those affected. It was overwhelming, but also incredibly inspiring. It made me realize charity wasn't just about religious obligations; it was about humanity.

unnormalised: Recently, I've been exploring online donation platforms. Websites like Milaap and Ketto showcase various causes, from medical emergencies needing ₹5 lakh for surgeries to educational initiatives requiring ₹2 lakh to support underprivileged students. The transparency is appealing; you can track where your Rs. 500 or Rs. 1000 goes.
normalised: Recently, I've been exploring online donation platforms. unnormalised: My friend, Aisha, runs a small NGO in Guwahati. She told me about the challenges of fundraising. Last year, they aimed to raise ₹3,00,000 for a new school building but only managed to collect Rs. 2,50,000. The shortfall meant delaying construction. It highlighted the constant need for support and the real impact even small contributions can have.
normalised: My friend, Aisha, runs a small N-G-O in Guwahati. She told me about the challenges of fundraising. Last year, they aimed to raise rupee three lakh for a new school building but only managed to collect rupees two lakh and fifty thousand. The shortfall meant delaying construction. It highlighted the constant need for support and the real impact even small contributions can have.

unnormalised: Thinking back to my grandmother and the Gurudwara, I understand now that every bit counts. Whether it’s Rs. 10 at a temple, ₹1000 online, or $20 to a global charity, it’s the intention and collective effort that truly make a difference. Knowing that even a small amount can contribute to someone's well-being is a powerful motivator to give back.
